
First we note that the "d" attribute of the path tag is a space-separated list of coordinates enclosed in quotes. The first two coordinates form the starting point of the shape, and the remaining coordinates form a series of straight lines that define the outline of the shape.

To identify the shape, we can analyze the number of vertices and the arrangement of the coordinates.

The SVG code has 5 sets of coordinates, which implies a 4-sided shape. The first two coordinates are 22.06,65.18, and the last two are 22.06,65.18. This means that the shape has two vertices at the same coordinates, which results in a shape with two sides that are identical in length, forming a shape with 4 sides.

However, we can find further evidence to disqualify some of the options.
We know that the shape is not a circle because it has 4 sides, which is not a characteristic of a circle. Beyond that, none of the coordinates outline a perfect circle.
We can rule out triangle (J) and all other three-sided shapes because we know the shape is a 4-sided polygon.
We can rule out trapezoid (K) because we know the shape is a polygon, and we see the defining characteristic of a trapezoid is the presence of one pair of parallel sides, which is not apparent in our coordinate set.
That leaves us with four possibilities: hexagon (C), heptagon (B), pentagon (G), and kite (D).
But we can further refine our possible shapes with additional analysis of the SVG coordinates.
The second pair of coordinates (22.58,64.52) and the fourth pair of coordinates (7.52,52.61) create the first diagonal. This diagonal separates the top right and bottom left corners of the shape, making it a 4-sided shape, so none of the remaining possibilities (C, B, G, and D) can be correct.
The fifth pair of coordinates (22.06,65.18) repeats the coordinates of the first pair, which means that the resulting shape has sides of equal length. This rules out the heptagon (B), kite (D), and pentagon (G) as possibilities, because none of these shapes have equal side lengths.

(C) hexagon
